awd_titl_txt: Light-induced liquid flow control for biomimetic retinal implants and therapies
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract:
 Retinal prosthesis is a type of neural prosthesis, which is an implant process to restore or treat damaged sensory elements in the neural system. It is well known that complex information transfer in neural cells is primarily through biochemical reactions. Neurotransmitter-based chemical stimulation is a relatively new concept and has demonstrated its potential to mimic neural information processing. However, most of the current efforts rely on limited cell numbers and their responses because of the lack of appropriate methods to investigate large cell populations. Neural cell arrangement in the retina is especially in a highly arrayed configuration. As such, their neural activities are interconnected with surrounding cells. To better understand the large-scale neural signal processing and develop clinically applicable neural prostheses, it is important to mimic the synaptic functionality of releasing neurotransmitters in a large, arrayed configuration with high spatial resolution. The proposed research work will provide a solution for this critical need and develop light-induced liquid flow control, especially for large-scale chemical stimulation. In addition to the technical impacts, the broader impact of the proposed program will be the education and training of a new generation of workforces for future scientific community. The City College of New York is well-positioned to attract its dominant underrepresented minorities. The project will integrate the research activities into the current curriculum to provide undergraduate and graduate students with hands-on experience and research opportunities. The proposed research activities will also be integrated into outreach activities through lab demos, tours, and summer internships for high school students. 

The overall goal of the proposed research program is to advance the scientific and technological 
foundations for large-arrayed neurotransmitter-based chemical stimulation with application to retinal prosthesis. The project will implement a self-powered, three-dimensional microfluidic platform to address the fundamental limitations of the current chemical stimulation approach when it is applied to highly interconnected, large arrayed neural stimulation. Two control mechanisms will be studied. One is based on light-induced electroosmotic effect, and the other is based on light-induced physical on-off valves using stimulus-responsive polymers. The successful completion of this project will significantly simplify overall system complexities for chemically stimulating densely populated cells and initiate a new paradigm of chemical stimulation that can be potentially applied to large-area, with high spatial resolution, without limiting its scalability. The resulting platform will have broad impacts of translating the current chemical stimulation approach from a bench-top laboratory setting to practical neural prostheses and therapies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The gradual degeneration of retinal photoreceptor cells, caused by incurable diseases like retinitis pigmentosa and macular degeneration, leads to permanent vision loss. Over the years, research and development in retinal prostheses have shown that stimulating surviving neurons using various neuromodulation technologies can partially restore vision. Chemical stimulation has been proposed as a potential method because it mimics natural synaptic communication between neurons using chemical neurotransmitters. It is well known that complex information transfer in neurons is primarily through chemical neurotransmitters. When neurons degenerate, this communication is disrupted, impairing their functions. The chemical stimulation approach aims to create artificial synaptic interfaces of the degenerated neurons and restore their damaged chemical signal pathways. While the conceptual implementation of chemical stimulation channels to modulate neurotransmitter flow to neurons is straightforward, the practical implementation of this approach poses a challenge when applied to retina prosthetic devices. A large arrayed chemical stimulator, capable of modulating neurotransmitter release on spatially localized neurons using light, is required to restore high-resolution visual function for retina prosthetic devices. Although current technologies are continuously developed to mimic neuro-chemical signaling, they have limitations in achieving the distinct need for functional visual restoration with controlled chemical release.

In this project, we investigated light-induced liquid flow structures and developed platforms for large-arrayed neurotransmitter-based chemical stimulation. Our research made significant progress in developing a light-induced, large-arrayed chemical stimulator. Considering that the current chemical stimulation approach often uses bulk external pumps with limited stimulation ports, our result significantly advanced the state of chemical stimulation tool development and its implementation. A range of different platforms have been developed through the project. We have demonstrated innovative approaches to scale the number of neurotransmitter release channels and develop ejection mechanisms directly using light. Particularly, a highly ordered porous silicon membrane was used as an arrayed microfluidic channel structure. Since the pore size and period could be easily controlled, this structure allowed a large arrayed microfluidic channel structure that could be engineered into a light-controlled stimulator.  Based on this unique structure, different types of valves that could be incorporated within pores were demonstrated. To create physical valves within pores, we studied the volume change of bio-compatible polymer materials, such as polypyrrole and temperature-sensitive N-isopropylacrylamide-based hydrogel. Electroactive valve arrays using polypyrrole were demonstrated with less than 1V applied voltage, which could be potentially connected to silicon-based photocells. Temperature-sensitive hydrogels were combined with plasmonic nano-particles (ex. Gold nanorods) to enable light-controlled volume change of the hydrogel. Bulk-hydrogel-based and grafted-hydrogel-based valves were successfully demonstrated to control the release of chemicals using light. Using fluorescein dye as a model chemical, we demonstrated its localized release using light. Temporal and spatial controls of the release were successfully demonstrated with our presented platforms. Since the operation of the proposed device is confirmed, we are in the stage of testing in-vitro neuronal cell response using the demonstrated platforms. While chemical stimulation requires long-term developments to answer many challenges, as we have witnessed similar efforts in electrical stimulation from decades of work from in-vitro, in-vivo, and clinical tries, the findings from this award open new avenues for future chemical stimulation approaches, offering promising platforms for use in retinal prostheses.
